user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_ip_addr_to_key:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
MHD_ip_addr_to_key (const struct sockaddr_storage *addr,
                    socklen_t addrlen,
                    struct MHD_IPCount *key)
{
  memset (key,
          0,
          sizeof(*key));

  /* IPv4 addresses */
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    if (AF_INET == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv4,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in *) addr)->sin_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in *) NULL)->sin_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }

#ifdef HAVE_INET6
  if (sizeof (struct sockaddr_in6) <= (size_t) addrlen)
  {
    /* IPv6 addresses */
    if (AF_INET6 == addr->ss_family)
    {
      key->family = AF_INET6;
      memcpy (&key->addr.ipv6,
              &((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) addr)->sin6_addr,
              sizeof(((const struct sockaddr_in6 *) NULL)->sin6_addr));
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
#endif

  /* Some other address */
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_ip_addr_to_key:

...

...
#define HAVE_INET6 1
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No uses of the Standard Library function memcmp are present in the provided code. The function only uses memset and memcpy to initialize and copy binary address structures (struct MHD_IPCount, in_addr, in6_addr), not to compare null‑terminated strings. The memcpy calls copy fixed-size binary address fields (sizes obtained via sizeof on in_addr/in6_addr), and the memset zeroes a structure; neither is a string comparison. There are no other calls or operations in the snippet that attempt to compare null‑terminated strings with memcmp, so no fragments need further investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
